clinical_study.brief_title: Immediate Effect of Sit to Stand and Stepping Training With External Feedback in Stroke Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Immediate Effects of Using External Feedback Relating to Ability of Lower-limb Support During Sit to Stand and Stepping in Ambulatory Patients With Stroke

brief_summary.textblock:
1. Are there differences in immediate changes following STS and stepping training with or without using external feedback in ambulatory patients with stroke?
2. Does STS and stepping training using of external feedback immediately change functional ability of ambulatory patients with stroke?
3. Does STS and stepping training without external feedback immediately change the functional ability of ambulatory patients with stroke?
4. How does the amount of LLSA on the affected leg during STS and stepping in ambulatory patients with stroke as compare to the data from healthy individuals?

detailed_description.textblock:
Subjects are patients with stroke, the age of over 40 years to 74 years, both males and females who are able to walk independently at least 10 meters. Most of them will be recruited from the Srinagarind hospital and communities in the Northeast area of Thailand. Subjects have to participate in STS and stepping training with and without using the external feedback for 1 time/condition with a wash-out period for 2 weeks (crossover design). The outcomes will be measured in terms of the amount of LLSA on the affected side during STS and stepping, walking speed, level walking symmetry, dynamic balance control.
The primary objective of this study is to compare immediate effects of amount and duration of LLSA of STS and stepping training with and without the use of external feedback in ambulatory patients with stroke. Secondary objective of study are to compare immediate changes after STS and stepping training with the use of external feedback relating to amount of LLSA in ambulatory patients with stroke, to compare immediate changes after STS and stepping training without the use of external feedback relating to amount of LLSA in ambulatory patients with stroke and to investigate amount of LLSA of the affected leg during STS and stepping in ambulatory patients with stroke as compare to healthy individuals.

primary_outcome.measure: Change of lower limb support ability (LLSA) by digital load cell
primary_outcome.time_frame: before training and immediately after complete training program in one session
primary_outcome.description: LLSA was assessed using digital load cells of the VWTM without turning on the displayed section. For the LLSA during STS, the subjects sat on the adjustable chair with placing their feet on two separated digital load cells. Then, they were instructed to stand up with the attempt to adequately control LLSA of each lower extremity. For the LLSA during stepping, subjects will stand in a step stance position with placing the affected leg on the load cells of VWTM and the non-affected leg slightly backward outside the load cells. Then they were instructed to step the non-affected leg forward and backward with the attempt to adequately shift their body-weight onto the affected leg as much as possible. The tests were performed for 5 trials, in which the first 2 trials served as practice trials, and the average outcomes over the other 3 trials were used in data analysis.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of walking speed by 10 meter-walk test (10MWT)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: before training and immediately after complete training program in one session
secondary_outcome.description: The subjects stood at the starting point of a 10-meter walkway with their feet behind the line. Then, they were instructed to walk at a preferred or comfortable speed along a straight line without any break to the endpoint with or without a walking device. Moreover, they were instructed to walk at the fastest speed. During walking, subjects were filmed while they walk along the middle 4-meter of the walkway using the digital camera with a frame rate of 60 Hz. The data were further analyzed for step length, stride length and cadence to convert for a walking speed using the method of manual digitization.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of dynamic balance control by Timed up and go test (TUGT)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: before training and immediately after complete training program in one session
secondary_outcome.description: The test was executed by the subjects sat on a standard armchair with their back upright 90 degrees against the backrest of the chair and their feet placed flat on the floor at 10 cm behind the knees. Then, they were required to stand up from the chair, walk 3 m, turned around a traffic cone, walked back to sit down on the chair at a preferred speed and safe manner with or without a walking device. The test was recorded the time taken in seconds from the command "Go" until the subject's back touch the backrest of the chair.

arm_group.description: Sit to Stand training with external feedback for 10 minute and then, stepping training with external feedback for 10 minutes. After training, subjects will walk overground for 10 minutes.
Sit to Stand training without external feedback for 10 minute and then, stepping training without external feedback for 10 minutes. After training, subjects will walk overground for 10 minutes.

intervention.description: Sit to stand and stepping training with external feedback , after that subjects will be instructed to overground walking
Sit to stand and stepping training without external feedback, after that subjects will be instructed to overground walking

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Independent ambulatory patients with chronic stroke (post-stroke time more than 6 months)
- Age at least 40 years to 74 years
- Body mass index (BMI) between 18.5- 29.9 kg/m^2
- Ability of independent walking over at least 10 meters with or without a walking device
- Ability to rise from a chair with or without using their arms
- Ability to follow a command used in the study
Exclusion Criteria:
any conditions that may affect ambulatory ability or ability to participate in the study, such as
- Auditory or visual deficits that are unable to be corrected by a hearing aid, glasses or contact lens
- Musculoskeletal pain with a pain scale more than 5 out of 10 on a visual analog scale (VAS)
- Deformity in the limbs or spine that affect ambulatory ability
- Modified Ashworth Scale (MAS) more 2 score
- Unstable cardiovascular, orthopedics, musculoskeletal, or neurological disease other than stroke.
